sen.j: 平 景隆（たいら の かげたか、生年不詳 - 文永11年10月15日 (旧暦)（1274年11月14日））は、鎌倉時代中期の九州の武士。
sen.e: TAIRA no Kagetaka (Year of birth unknown - November 14, 1274) was a Samurai of Kyushu in the mid Kamakura period.
TAIRA no Kagetaka (year of birth unknown - November 14, 1274) was a samurai in Kyushu who lived during the mid Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 鎌倉時代中期の→who lived during the mid Kamakura period（"who lived during"の表現に変更しました。）九州の→in Kyushu武士→samurai（小文字に変更しました。）
sen.e: TAIRA no Kagetaka (year of birth unknown - November 14, 1274) was a samurai in Kyushu who lived during the mid Kamakura period.
His common name was Naizaemon.
He was commonly called Naizaemon.
He was commonly called Naizaemon.
He was called TAIRA no Tsunetaka or TAIRA no Kagetaka.
While he was also known as TAIRA no Tsunetaka, Kagetaka, can be written as '景隆' or '景高.'
sen.cmt: 「平経高」は、別称となりますが、「平景高」は、「平景隆」と読み方は同じですが、漢字表記が異なるので、変更しました。
sen.e: While he was also known as TAIRA no Tsunetaka, Kagetaka, can be written as '景隆' or '景高.'

sen.j: 壱岐国の守護代として文永の役にあたる。
sen.e: He dealt with the Bunei War as Shugodai (the acting Military Governor) of Iki Province.
He dealt with the Bunei War as Shugodai (the acting Military Governor) of Iki Province.
He dealt with the Bunei War as Shugodai (the acting Military Governor) of Iki Province.

sen.j: 壱岐の守護は少弐氏で、景隆はその家人であったと思われる。
sen.e: Shugo (a provincial military governor) of Iki Province was the Shoni clan and Kagetaka is thought to have been a Kenin (retainer) of the clan.
It is considered that Kagetaka was a retainer of the Shoni clan who held the office of Shugo (a provincial military governor) of Iki Province.
sen.cmt: 関係代名詞を使い、簡潔な表現としました。
sen.e: It is considered that Kagetaka was a retainer of the Shoni clan who held the office of Shugo (a provincial military governor) of Iki Province.

sen.j: 『八幡愚童訓』によれば、文永11年（1274年）10月14日の申の刻（午後4時から6時頃）、蒙古軍が壱岐島の西岸に上陸すると、景隆は百余騎の武士を率いて迎え撃ち、庄三郎という者の城の前で矢を射かけて合戦となる。
sen.e: According to the Hachiman Gudokun (Exegesis of Hachimanshin (God of War) Legends for the Ignorant and Children), when the Mongolian forces landed on the west coast of Ikinoshima Island at the Hour of the Monkey (4-6 p.m.) on November 20, 1274, Kagetaka received the enemy leading over 100 samurai horsemen and the battle started by shooting an arrow in front of the castle of a person named Shozaburo.
sen.cmt: 「文永11年10月14日」＝グレゴリオ暦「西暦1274年11月20日」、出典：http://maechan.net/kanreki
sen.e: "Hachiman Gudokun" (Exegesis of Hachimanshin (God of War) Legends for the Ignorant and Children) mentioned that when the Mongolian forces landed on the west coast of Ikinoshima Island at Saru-no-koku (ninth sign of Chinese zodiac (The Monkey, 4pm to 6pm.) on November 20, 1274, Kagetaka waiting with about 100 samurai horsemen attacked the Mongolian forces, and shot an arrow toward them in front of the castle of a person named Shozaburo, and then, this attack developed to a battle.
sen.cmt: 『八幡愚童訓』→"Hachiman Gudokun" (Exegesis of Hachimanshin (God of War) Legends for the Ignorant and Children)（二重カッコとなっておりますので、クォーテーション・マークを付けました。）申の刻→at Saru-no-koku (ninth sign of Chinese zodiac (The Monkey, 4pm to 6pm.)
sen.e: "Hachiman Gudokun" (Exegesis of Hachimanshin (God of War) Legends for the Ignorant and Children) mentioned that when the Mongolian forces landed on the west coast of Ikinoshima Island at Saru-no-koku (ninth sign of Chinese zodiac (The Monkey, 4pm to 6pm.) on November 20, 1274, Kagetaka waiting with about 100 samurai horsemen attacked the Mongolian forces, and shot an arrow toward them in front of the castle of a person named Shozaburo, and then, this attack developed to a battle.

sen.j: しかし大勢で押し寄せ矢が二町（約216m）ほども射程がある蒙古軍にかなうはずもなく、景隆らは守護所の詰城である樋詰城に立て籠もって防戦した。
sen.e: However, there was no possibility of winning against the Mongolian forces of such size having bows with a range of Nicho (about 216 meters) and so Kagetaka and his forces fought in defense entrenching themselves in the Hinotsume-jo Castle which was a Tsume-no-shiro (the castle that guards the back of the main castle and serves as a retreat point when the main castle can no longer be defended) of Shugosho (provincial administration).

However, the Kagetaka's army defended against the Mongolian forces by staying in Hinotsume-jo Castle which was tsume-no-shiro (the castle that guards the back of the main castle and serves as a retreat point when the main castle can no longer be defended) of shugosho (provincial administration) because they had no chance of defeating the Mongolian forces which consisted of significant number of soldiers and could shoot arrows as far as about 216 meters.

However, the Kagetaka's army defended against the Mongolian forces by staying in Hinotsume-jo Castle which was tsume-no-shiro (the castle that guards the back of the main castle and serves as a retreat point when the main castle can no longer be defended) of shugosho (provincial administration) because they had no chance of defeating the Mongolian forces which consisted of significant number of soldiers and could shoot arrows as far as about 216 meters.

sen.j: 日没とともに蒙古軍は船団に引き上げ、翌日景隆が篭る樋詰城を包囲し攻め立てた。
sen.e: The Mongolian forces withdrew to their fleet at sundown and next day enveloped and attacked the Hinotsume-jo Castle in which Kagetaka holed up.
The Mongolian forces withdrew to their fleet at sundown, and on the following day, they besieged and attacked Hinotsume-jo Castle where the Kagetaka's army holed up.
sen.cmt: 景隆が篭る樋詰城→Hinotsume-jo Castle where the Kagetaka's army holed up（上記において、「景隆らは」となるので、"the Kagetaka's army"としました。）
sen.e: The Mongolian forces withdrew to their fleet at sundown, and on the following day, they besieged and attacked Hinotsume-jo Castle where the Kagetaka's army holed up.

sen.j: 景隆一同は城中で自害し、下人の宗三郎を大宰府の守護のもとに派遣して状況を報告させた。
sen.e: Kagetaka and his followers killed themselves in the Castle sending Sozaburo, Genin (servants who served to their masters as slaves) to Shugo (a provincial military governor) in Dazaifu (local government office in Kyushu region) to report on the situation.

Kagetaka and his followers killed themselves in the Castle, and Sozaburo, genin (manservant), went to Shugo (a provincial military governor) in Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region) and reported on the situation as he had been ordered by Kagetaka.
sen.cmt: 自害した後に下人を派遣して状況を報告させることはできないので、整合性をもたせるため、「景隆の命令に従い、守護のもとに行った」としました。
sen.e: Kagetaka and his followers killed themselves in the Castle, and Sozaburo, genin (manservant), went to Shugo (a provincial military governor) in Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region) and reported on the situation as he had been ordered by Kagetaka.

sen.j: 景隆の自害により蒙古軍は壱岐を制圧し、多数の島民が殺害された。
sen.e: Due to Kagetaka's suicide, the Mongolian forces brought Iki under their control and many inhabitants were killed.
Due to Kagetaka's suicide, the Mongolian forces took Iki in control, and killed many islanders.
sen.cmt: "the Mongolian forces"を主語としているので、後半部分も、"the Mongolian forces"を主語とする文章に変更しました。島民→islanders
sen.e: Due to Kagetaka's suicide, the Mongolian forces took Iki in control, and killed many islanders.

sen.j: 明治維新後、全国的に忠臣の顕彰運動が高まり、刀伊の入寇、弘安の役の戦死者とともに新城神社（長崎県壱岐市勝本町）に祀られた。
sen.e: After Meiji Restoration, a movement to honor loyal subjects publicly for an unrecognized good deed spread all over the country and he was deitied in the Shinjo Shrine (Katsumoto-cho, Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture) with the war dead in the Toi invasion and the Koan no eki (second Mongol invasions).

After the Meiji Restoration, he was deified in Shinjo-jinja Shrine (Katsumoto-cho, Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture) with people killed in the Toi invasion and the Koan War (second Mongol invasions), due to nationwide uprising of movement to honor loyal subjects publicly for their unrecognized good deeds.
sen.cmt: 英語らしい表現にするため、結論、理由の順に変更しました。祀られた→deified
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, he was deified in Shinjo-jinja Shrine (Katsumoto-cho, Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture) with people killed in the Toi invasion and the Koan War (second Mongol invasions), due to nationwide uprising of movement to honor loyal subjects publicly for their unrecognized good deeds.

sen.j: 明治（1886年）19年11月2日、正四位を追贈された。
sen.e: On November 2, 1886, the court rank of Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) was conferred posthumously to him.
On November 2, 1886, he was raised to Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) after his death.
sen.cmt: ～を追贈された→was raised to ～ after his death
sen.e: On November 2, 1886, he was raised to Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) after his death.
